epidemiology: Chronic inflammatory airway disease affecting ~300 million people globally. More common in children and young adults.
treatment_protocol: Stepwise therapy: SABA → ICS → LABA + ICS → Add-ons

epidemiology: Third leading cause of death globally. Strongly associated with smoking and environmental pollutants.

emergency_markers: Acute exacerbation with hypercapnia or hypoxia

treatment_protocol: Stage-based approach with GOLD classification

epidemiology: Leading cause of infectious death worldwide. Common in elderly and immunocompromised.

definitive: Empiric antibiotics based on severity and setting

treatment_protocol: CURB-65 or PSI score guides admission and antibiotics

epidemiology: Common cause of sudden death. Often from deep vein thrombosis. Higher risk in immobilized or post-op patients.
treatment_protocol: Wells score → Imaging → Anticoagulation

epidemiology: Global health burden. Highly endemic in sub-Saharan Africa, Southeast Asia. Spread by airborne droplets.

definitive: RIPE regimen: Rifampicin, Isoniazid, Pyrazinamide, Ethambutol

treatment_protocol: RIPE x 2 months → RI x 4 months

epidemiology: Spontaneous in tall, thin young males or due to trauma/underlying lung disease.
treatment_protocol: Stable → Observation/O2; Unstable → Decompression + Chest tube

epidemiology: A group of disorders characterized by inflammation and fibrosis of lung interstitium. Prevalence increases with age.
treatment_protocol: Confirm diagnosis → Manage inflammation → Consider transplant

epidemiology: Multisystem granulomatous disease; most commonly affects lungs. Higher incidence in young adults and African descent.
treatment_protocol: Observe or treat depending on severity/organ involvement

epidemiology: Common sleep-related breathing disorder. Prevalence higher in obese males over 40 years old.
treatment_protocol: Sleep study → CPAP or alternative interventions

epidemiology: Chronic disease with permanent dilation of bronchi due to repeated infections. Often post-TB or congenital.
treatment_protocol: Pulmonary hygiene → Antibiotics → Monitor function

epidemiology: Life-threatening lung injury due to various insults (sepsis, trauma, aspiration). Mortality 30–40%.
treatment_protocol: ARDS protocol → Treat cause → Lung-protective ventilation

epidemiology: Immune-mediated inflammatory lung disease caused by inhalation of environmental antigens (e.g., mold, bird proteins).
treatment_protocol: Remove antigen → Corticosteroids → Monitor for chronic fibrosis

epidemiology: Localized collection of pus in the lung parenchyma. Often due to aspiration pneumonia in alcoholics or neurologically impaired.

definitive: Percutaneous drainage or surgery if no improvement

treatment_protocol: IV antibiotics → Reassess → Drain if persistent

epidemiology: Increased pressure in pulmonary arteries. Classified into 5 groups by WHO. Idiopathic form is rare and severe.
treatment_protocol: Confirm group → Targeted therapy → Supportive care

epidemiology: Chemical lung injury due to inhalation of gastric contents. Seen in patients with altered consciousness or swallowing dysfunction.
treatment_protocol: Supportive care → Monitor for infection

epidemiology: Abnormal fluid accumulation in pleural space. Common in CHF, infections, malignancy.
treatment_protocol: Drainage → Identify cause → Treat underlying pathology

epidemiology: Blockage of pulmonary artery due to thrombus. Common cause of sudden death in hospitalized patients.
treatment_protocol: Risk stratify → Start anticoagulation → Consider lysis/embolectomy

epidemiology: Air in pleural space causing lung collapse. Primary (spontaneous) or secondary (underlying lung disease).
treatment_protocol: Stabilize → Chest tube or needle → Monitor

epidemiology: Chronic infection by Mycobacterium tuberculosis. Endemic in developing countries; airborne transmission.
treatment_protocol: RIPE x 2 months → RI x 4 months → Monitor sputum & liver function

epidemiology: Cough lasting more than 8 weeks, often due to GERD, postnasal drip, or asthma. More common in non-smokers.
treatment_protocol: Evaluate causes → Targeted therapy → Reassess

epidemiology: Leading cause of cancer-related death worldwide. Most common types are NSCLC and SCLC. Strongly linked to smoking.
treatment_protocol: Stage → MDT plan → Treatment modality based on type & stage

epidemiology: Progressive scarring of lung tissue. Most common in older adults. Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) is the most severe type.
treatment_protocol: Confirm IPF → Antifibrotics → Transplant evaluation

epidemiology: Severe acute lung injury leading to hypoxemia and respiratory failure. Common in sepsis, trauma, or pneumonia.
treatment_protocol: ICU → Lung-protective ventilation → Manage cause

epidemiology: Intermittent upper airway collapse during sleep. Affects ~5-10% of adults, especially obese males.
treatment_protocol: Diagnose → Initiate CPAP → Monitor adherence

epidemiology: Hypersensitivity reaction to Aspergillus in patients with asthma or cystic fibrosis.

emergency_markers: Severe exacerbation of asthma with ABPA features

treatment_protocol: Steroids → Monitor IgE → Add antifungals if recurrent

epidemiology: Common viral lower respiratory tract infection in infants. Peaks in winter. Leading cause of bronchiolitis in children < 2 years.
treatment_protocol: Supportive → Hospitalize if hypoxic or dehydrated

epidemiology: Autosomal recessive disorder affecting chloride channels, leading to thick mucus secretions. Common in Caucasians.
treatment_protocol: Confirm diagnosis → Multidisciplinary care → Targeted therapy

epidemiology: Common viral lower respiratory tract infection in children < 2 years, usually due to RSV.
treatment_protocol: Assess severity → Supportive care → Hospitalize if needed

epidemiology: Pneumoconiosis caused by inhalation of silica dust. Common in miners, sandblasters, and construction workers.
treatment_protocol: Remove exposure → Supportive care → Monitor for TB

epidemiology: Interstitial lung disease from asbestos exposure. Long latency. Seen in shipyard workers, insulation industry.

definitive: No specific treatment; monitor for malignancy

treatment_protocol: Supportive → Surveillance for cancer → Manage fibrosis

epidemiology: Zoonotic viral disease from rodent droppings. Rare but potentially fatal respiratory illness.
risk_factors: Exposure to rodents or rodent-infested areas

definitive: No antiviral proven; supportive care is mainstay

treatment_protocol: Early recognition → ICU → Manage respiratory failure

epidemiology: Permanent dilation of bronchi due to chronic infection or inflammation. Prevalence higher in elderly and post-TB cases.
treatment_protocol: Manage infections → Airway clearance → Consider resection

epidemiology: Multisystem granulomatous disease with pulmonary involvement in >90% cases. Common in young adults and African descent.
treatment_protocol: Mild → Monitor | Moderate-severe → Steroids

epidemiology: Blockage of pulmonary artery by thrombus. Common cause of sudden death. Risk increased in immobility, surgery, malignancy.
treatment_protocol: Risk stratify → Anticoagulate → Consider thrombolysis

epidemiology: Elevated pulmonary artery pressure > 25 mmHg. Associated with heart/lung disease, idiopathic forms more common in females.
treatment_protocol: Classify WHO group → Tailor therapy

epidemiology: Interstitial lung disease from inhalation of coal dust particles. Common in miners.
treatment_protocol: Confirm diagnosis → Eliminate exposure → Monitor and support

epidemiology: Seen in obese patients with BMI >30, characterized by chronic hypercapnia without other causes. Prevalent in 10–20% of severely obese individuals.
treatment_protocol: Confirm diagnosis → Initiate BiPAP → Lifestyle changes

epidemiology: Localized suppurative infection of lung parenchyma. Common in alcoholics, aspiration, or post-pneumonia.
treatment_protocol: Antibiotics → Monitor → Drain if unresolved

epidemiology: Rare lung disease where surfactant accumulates in alveoli. Seen in autoimmune, congenital, or secondary forms (e.g. dust exposure).
treatment_protocol: Diagnose → Lavage → Immunotherapy if refractory

epidemiology: Inflammatory lung reaction to inhaled organic dusts (e.g. bird proteins, mold). Also called extrinsic allergic alveolitis.
treatment_protocol: Remove antigen → Steroids → Monitor fibrosis

epidemiology: Rare lung disease in women of childbearing age. Linked with tuberous sclerosis. Causes cystic lung destruction.
treatment_protocol: Diagnose → mTOR inhibitors → Transplant if needed

epidemiology: Rare cause of pulmonary hemorrhage, often seen in autoimmune vasculitides like GPA or microscopic polyangiitis.
treatment_protocol: Treat vasculitis → Immunosuppressive therapy → Plasmapheresis in severe cases

epidemiology: Rare interstitial lung disease associated with smoking. Most common in young adult smokers.
treatment_protocol: Stop smoking → Monitor → Treat inflammation if progressive

epidemiology: Weakening of tracheal cartilage leading to airway collapse, especially during expiration. Can be congenital or acquired.
treatment_protocol: Supportive therapy → Surgery if severe

epidemiology: Common viral infection in infants <2 years, leading cause of hospitalization in infants. Peaks in winter.
treatment_protocol: Supportive → Hospitalize if severe

epidemiology: Life-threatening condition from accumulation of air under pressure in pleural space. Common after trauma or mechanical ventilation.
treatment_protocol: Immediate needle decompression → Chest tube
